name: neanderthals-thrive-europe
description: Neanderthals dominated Europe for over 200,000 years, developing sophisticated tools and social structures before modern humans arrived.

name: first-irrigation-systems
description: Ancient Mesopotamians developed canal systems to control water flow, enabling large-scale agriculture and the rise of civilization.

name: minoan-civilization-peak
description: The Minoan civilization on Crete reached its height, building elaborate palaces like Knossos and dominating Aegean trade.

name: abrahams-journey-traditional
description: According to tradition, Abraham migrated from Ur to Canaan, establishing the covenant that founded the Abrahamic faiths.

name: david-establishes-jerusalem-capital
description: King David captured Jerusalem from the Jebusites and made it the political and religious capital of the united Israelite kingdom.

name: assyrian-empire-expansion
description: The Neo-Assyrian Empire began aggressive expansion, becoming the first true empire to rule much of the ancient Near East.

name: fall-of-israel-northern-kingdom
description: Assyria conquered the northern Kingdom of Israel, deporting its population and ending the Ten Tribes as a distinct entity.

name: fall-of-nineveh
description: A coalition of Babylonians and Medes destroyed Nineveh, ending the Assyrian Empire after centuries of dominance.

name: caesar-invades-britain
description: Julius Caesar led two expeditions to Britain, the first Roman military operations on the island, though no permanent conquest resulted.

name: five-good-emperors-era-begins
description: Nerva's accession began Rome's most stable period, with emperors chosen by merit rather than heredity for nearly a century.

name: end-of-pax-romana
description: The death of Marcus Aurelius ended two centuries of relative peace and prosperity, beginning Rome's slow decline.

name: visigoths-settle-aquitaine
description: Rome granted the Visigoths land in southwestern Gaul as foederati, establishing the first Germanic kingdom within the empire.

name: theodoric-establishes-ostrogothic-kingdom
description: Theodoric the Great conquered Italy and established the Ostrogothic Kingdom, preserving Roman institutions under Gothic rule.

name: baghdad-founded
description: Caliph al-Mansur founded Baghdad as the new Abbasid capital, which became the world's largest city and center of learning.

name: treaty-of-aachen
description: The Byzantine Empire recognized Charlemagne as Emperor of the West, acknowledging the permanent division of the Roman legacy.

name: rurik-founds-novgorod
description: The Varangian prince Rurik established rule at Novgorod, founding the dynasty that would rule Russia for over 700 years.

name: fatimids-conquer-egypt
description: The Fatimid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo, establishing a rival Shia caliphate to challenge Abbasid authority.

name: seljuk-turks-capture-baghdad
description: The Seljuk Turks entered Baghdad and became the real power behind the Abbasid caliphs, reshaping the Islamic world.

name: investiture-controversy-begins
description: Pope Gregory VII and Emperor Henry IV clashed over the right to appoint church officials, sparking a decades-long power struggle.

name: walk-to-canossa
description: Emperor Henry IV stood barefoot in the snow for three days seeking Pope Gregory VII's forgiveness after excommunication.

name: toledo-reconquered
description: Alfonso VI of Castile captured Toledo, a major Reconquista victory that recovered the former Visigothic capital from Muslim rule.

name: fall-of-edessa
description: Zengi captured the Crusader County of Edessa, the first Crusader state to fall, triggering the Second Crusade.

name: minamoto-yoritomo-becomes-shogun
description: Minamoto Yoritomo was named shogun, establishing the Kamakura shogunate and beginning seven centuries of samurai rule in Japan.

name: mamluks-take-power-egypt
description: The Mamluks, former slave soldiers, seized power in Egypt and would later halt the Mongol advance at Ain Jalut.

name: sicilian-vespers
description: A popular uprising in Palermo led to the massacre of French Angevins, ending French rule and bringing Aragon to power in Sicily.

name: henry-iv-deposes-richard-ii
description: Henry Bolingbroke deposed Richard II and became Henry IV, founding the Lancastrian dynasty and setting the stage for civil war.

name: council-of-florence
description: The Council attempted to reunite the Eastern and Western churches, briefly achieving union before Byzantine rejection.

name: portuguese-capture-goa
description: Afonso de Albuquerque conquered Goa, establishing it as the capital of Portuguese India and a major trading hub for four centuries.

name: augsburg-confession
description: Lutheran princes presented their confession of faith to Emperor Charles V, formally establishing Protestant doctrine.

name: pizarro-executes-atahualpa
description: Spanish conquistador Francisco Pizarro executed the Inca emperor Atahualpa despite receiving history's largest ransom.

name: dissolution-of-monasteries
description: Henry VIII began dissolving English monasteries, seizing their wealth and redistributing lands to loyal supporters.

name: servetus-burned-at-stake
description: Michael Servetus was burned for heresy in Calvin's Geneva for denying the Trinity, showing Protestant intolerance of dissent.

name: mercator-projection-map
description: Gerardus Mercator published his world map with a new projection that enabled straight-line navigation, revolutionizing seafaring.

name: execution-mary-queen-scots
friendly_name: Execution of Mary Queen of Scots
description: Elizabeth I executed her Catholic cousin Mary Stuart after years of imprisonment, removing a rival claimant to the English throne.

name: first-korean-turtle-ships
description: Admiral Yi Sun-sin deployed armored turtle ships against the Japanese navy, helping Korea resist Toyotomi Hideyoshi's invasion.

name: giordano-bruno-burned
description: The philosopher Giordano Bruno was burned at the stake in Rome for heresy, including his belief in an infinite universe.

name: gunpowder-plot
description: Guy Fawkes and Catholic conspirators attempted to blow up Parliament and King James I, but the plot was discovered and foiled.

name: defenestration-of-prague
description: Protestant nobles threw Catholic officials from a window in Prague Castle, sparking the Thirty Years' War.

name: great-migration-massachusetts
description: Over 20,000 Puritans migrated to Massachusetts Bay Colony in a decade, establishing English Protestant settlements in New England.

name: galileos-trial
description: The Inquisition tried Galileo for supporting heliocentrism, forcing him to recant and placing him under house arrest for life.

name: putney-debates
description: New Model Army officers and soldiers debated England's future constitution, with radicals arguing for expanded voting rights.

name: treaty-of-pereyaslav
description: Ukrainian Cossacks agreed to Russian protection, beginning the process that would bring Ukraine under Muscovite control.

name: royal-society-founded
description: Scientists founded the Royal Society of London, the world's oldest national scientific institution still in existence.

name: kangxi-emperor-begins-reign
description: The Kangxi Emperor began his 61-year reign, the longest in Chinese history, consolidating Qing rule and expanding the empire.

name: hudsons-bay-company-founded
description: Charles II granted a royal charter creating the Hudson's Bay Company, which would control much of North American fur trade.

name: pennsylvania-founded
description: William Penn received a charter for Pennsylvania, establishing it as a Quaker colony with religious tolerance and fair Native treaties.

name: salem-witch-trials
description: Mass hysteria in colonial Massachusetts led to the execution of twenty people accused of witchcraft before sanity prevailed.

name: treaty-of-rastatt
description: Austria and France ended the War of Spanish Succession, with Austria gaining the Spanish Netherlands and Italian territories.

name: first-freemason-grand-lodge
description: Four London lodges formed the first Grand Lodge of Freemasonry, beginning the organization's formal institutional structure.

name: south-sea-bubble
description: The South Sea Company's stock collapsed after massive speculation, ruining investors and causing Britain's first financial crisis.

name: robert-walpole-first-pm
description: Robert Walpole became First Lord of the Treasury, effectively creating the role of Prime Minister in British government.

name: treaty-of-nystad
description: Russia and Sweden ended the Great Northern War, with Russia gaining Baltic territories and emerging as a major European power.

name: first-saudi-state-established
description: Muhammad ibn Saud allied with Islamic reformer Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab, founding the first Saudi state in Arabia.

name: black-hole-of-calcutta
description: British prisoners allegedly died in an overcrowded cell in Calcutta, becoming propaganda justifying British conquest of Bengal.

name: rousseaus-social-contract
description: Jean-Jacques Rousseau published his influential political philosophy arguing that legitimate rule requires popular consent.

name: stamp-act
description: Britain imposed direct taxation on American colonies, sparking protests and the slogan 'no taxation without representation.'

name: france-enters-american-revolution
description: France formally allied with the American colonies against Britain, providing crucial military and financial support for independence.

name: watts-rotary-steam-engine
description: James Watt patented the rotary steam engine, enabling steam power to drive machinery and accelerating the Industrial Revolution.

name: us-constitution-written
description: Delegates in Philadelphia drafted the US Constitution, creating a federal system with separation of powers still in use today.

name: tennis-court-oath
description: French National Assembly members swore not to disband until they had written a constitution, defying royal authority.

name: first-bank-united-states
friendly_name: First Bank of the United States
description: Alexander Hamilton established the First Bank of the United States to manage government finances and stabilize the economy.

name: execution-of-robespierre
description: Maximilien Robespierre was guillotined during the Thermidorian Reaction, ending the Terror and the radical phase of the Revolution.

name: malthus-essay-population
description: Thomas Malthus argued that population growth would outpace food supply, influencing economics and Darwin's evolution theory.

name: napoleons-egyptian-campaign
description: Napoleon invaded Egypt to threaten British India, bringing scientists who discovered the Rosetta Stone during the expedition.

name: act-of-union-ireland
description: Britain and Ireland merged their parliaments, creating the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
